paragraphs.text: I'd be crazy not to ask this question. Recently you were on 60 Minutes, and you talked about AI potentially curing all diseases within the next decade. How would that exactly work?

Regulation slow things down? Yeah. So let me just clarify what I meant by there, and you can have the scoop on this. What I was meaning was a platform that could come up with many hundreds of drugs. Now, whether or not, of course, there's all the FDA and all the other regulatory approvals and things like that, that might change over time, probably slower than a decade. So that doesn't mean those potential cures wouldn't exist in the world. Maybe it'll take another decade to get it through all the processes and regulation.

But on the other hand, I could imagine once those types of drugs are proven out, maybe the first five or six AI-designed drugs, we can back-test whether the predictions were right on them in terms of side effects and that kind of thing. And then you might update the regulatory to be, you know, they accept the predictions a little bit more that they're reliable or statistically know how much reliability there is in that. So I can imagine that changing over time too. But first things first, we've got to build out our biochemistry and build on top of AlphaFold and build all of our new small molecule design systems and so on, which is going very well at Isomorphic. But we've got a good few years of that to do first, and then we'll see about the next steps.

So accelerating personalized treatment is really what AI will help with, I think so. And look, the thing I point back to is a lot of people are skeptical about that timeline, and they're probably, it's very reasonable to be skeptical of that because usually it takes a decade to do one drug, and you're doing well if that's the case. But it's the same thing that we were told when we started AlphaFold. You know, it takes a PhD student, rule of thumb, basically their whole PhD to crystallize and find the structure of one protein, five years on average, one protein. And now with AlphaFold, we've done all 200 million proteins known to science in one year, which is a billion years of PhD time. So we've done it once in what was thought to be a kind of uncrackable problem, a grand challenge of biology. This is harder, of course, because of the human body, but I'm optimistic it's possible, and we're going to try really, really hard to do it.
